Hic oritur quaestio Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 4, c. 1, [n.1], (I, 77, ll. 22-23). . This is the fourth distinction, which continues the preceding because, after the Master determined about the unity of the essence and the trinity of persons, then in this part he determines about their origin and their difference. And it is divided into four parts according to which the Master does four things. In the first place he introduces the question, in the second place he argues through reason, in the third place responds to a doubt, and in the fourth place he puts the solution of the argument. The second begins at
si enim Deus genuit Deum Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 4, c. 1, [n.1], (I, 77, ll. 24). . The third at
ad quod respondentes dicimus Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 4, c. 1, [n.1/2], (I, 78, ll. 3). . The fourth at
nunc ad praemissam dubitationem seu quaestionem
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 4, c. 2, [n. 5], (XXX). . And this is the division of the distinction in general.

head.supplied: Question: whether God eternally generated God before he produced a dependent bodily being?

div.p: Whether God eternally generated God before he produced a dependent bodily being?

That not because God did not generate God, therefore. The consequence is clear, and the antecedent is proved because God did not generate another God different from himself, therefore he did not generate God. The consequence holds because nothing is able to generate itself nor another because then there would be many gods, therefore etc.

In the second place, if he generated a God different than himself, it follows that there would be some reason signaling why one would generate another distinct from itself rather than the other. The consequent is false because there is no such reason discoverable of giveable for one that does not equally apply to the other, even in the case of an infinity of things.

In the third place, the Son in the divine began to be, therefore hew was not before etc. The consequence holds and the antecedent is proved because the Son is in some instant and was never before that instant, therefore in this instant he began to be. This is confirmed because the Son began to be in some instant because, if did not begin to be etc., it follows that he did not begin to be in this instant, which is false.

In opposition is
the Master in this distinction
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 4, c. 1, [n.2], (I, 78, ll. 15-33).
because
Athansius in Symbolo
says
eternal Father eternal Son Symbolum S. Athansii
etc.

First conclusion: though the Virgin Maria conceived the same son temporally which God the Father generated eternally, nevertheless the Virgin Mother conceived something that God the Father did not generate. The first is clear because the son of God the Father and of the Virgin Mary is the same thing. The second is clear because the Virgin conceived the body of Christ and God the Father did not generate this.

The first corollary: though Christ was eternally, nevertheless he temporally
began to be Christ. The first part is clear because the Son was eternally. The second part is clear because he began to be man temporally, therefore he temporally began to be Christ. The consequence holds because, just as the rational soul and the body are one man, so God and man are one Christ.
The second corollary: though there was some man eternally, nevertheless whatever is a man came to be a man temporally.

Third corollary: this demonstration does not follow, he was in Christ eteranlly, therefore he did not begin to be man temporally. This is clear from the same means because the humanity of Christ began to be temporally.

Another corollary: though Christ is necessarily as much the Son, as he is God, nevertheless Christ is contingently the son of someone. The first is clear because as the Father is necessarily the Father, so the Son is necessarily the Son and both are God. The second is clear because he is contingently the son of the Virgin.

Second conclusion: though with respect to us it is not evidently probable that ther eare not many sons in the divine, nevertheless it is necessary that God the Father begets a single Son coeternal and consubstantial with himself. The first is clear because every means evident to us for inferring that the father generates one son is able to infer equally the Son produces another Son because all three persons are of the same perfection, omnipotence, and activity. The second is clear in the present distinction. Again, it is clear through Augusine in book VI De Trinitate, in the secon chapter,
the Son is God from God but not except through generation Augustinus, De Trinitate VI, 2 (PL ??) , therefore etc. This is confirmed because de facto God the Father produced or beget only one Son equal to himself in every respect, therefore it necessary that this is so. The consequence is clear from what has been said above. The antecedent is a catholic truth.
The first corollary: that it is not able to be demonstrated to us in this life that there is one Son any more than it is an infinity are generated. The conclusion is clear.

Second corollary: it is not evidently probable that there are productions of diverse types in the divine. This is clear because by faith alone it is held that there are only two, namely generation and spiration.

Third corollary: just as there are many necessary things which are not demonstrably necessarily evident, so many things are impossible which even imply a contradiction to which no one is able to be led through natural reason alone. The first part is clear from the articles of faith that are signifying the Trinity. The second is clear because the statement that Father does not generate the Son includes a hidden contradiction which no one in the natural light is able to illuminate or show demonstratively to another.

Third conclusion: thought God the Father eternally generated God the Son, it is nevertheless not properly said that after his generation he produced something temporally. The first is clear through what has been said and it is able to be confirmed through Psalm 2
Dominus dixit ad me Filius meus est tu, ego hodie genui te Psalmus 2:7 . The second is proved because any divine act internal to itself is measured in an instant of eternity, therefore terms conveying a lapse or difference of time are no properly said about the divine. The consequence holds because after, before, when, and similar terms deal with differences of time. The antecedent is clear through Augustine in Psalm 101 where he says:
Aeternitas ipsa dei substantia est, quae nihil habet mutabile; ibi nihil est praeteritum quasi iam non sit, nihil est futurum quasi nondum sit; non est ibi, nisi est; non est ibi, fuit vel erit Augustine, Commentary on Ps. 25 . Again, Item, the same author in book XII De civitate Dei, in chapter 15:
Istae divisiones seu dimensiones temporalium spatiorum quae usitate et proprie dicuntur tempora a motu siderum ceperunt unde etiam Deus, cum instituit, dixit: Et sint in signa et tempora et dies et annos
Augustine, De civitate Dei, XII, capitulo 15 . Again, the same author in 83 questions,
Filius Dei debet dici natus, quia semper nascitur, quia eius nativitas seu generatio numquam praeteriit, sed semper praesens est
Augustinus, De diversis quaestionibus octoginta tribus, q.37 (CCSL 44A, 59, ll. 6-7). Note that Gracilis explicitly identifies this quotation as rough paraphrase. See his note that immedieately follows. . See the text because these words are not the precise words. Nevertheless not that there it is not always taken for a temporal difference, but for an eternal measure or instant.

The first corollary: though God the Father before the creation of things did not generate his son, nevertheless no
created thing was coeternal with him. The first is clear like the conclusion because, just as there is not after in eternity, so there is not before. The second is clear because otherwise God would not have produced from the beginning of time, which is false because God created etc.

The second corollary: in some sign or instant the Father generates and he never generates before that moment. And nevertheless the Father does not begin to generate because the Father generates in an instant of eternity and never before that moment because before that moment there was not instant.

Third corollary: though the Father in some instant generates the son and will never generate him after that moment, nevertheless he will not cease to generate and does not cease. This is clear from nature of the instant of eternity because after that instant nothing is or will be. From these things the negative part of the title is clear, namely that before corporeal being was made temporally made God generated God the Son eternally. This is clear when taking before in the matter stated.

Against the first conclusion: in the divine there is no motion, therefore there is no generation. The consequence holds because every motion is a generation. The antecedent is clear
in first book of James Iacobus 1:? .

In the second place, the Virgin did not beget anything except a creature, but the Son of God is not a creature, therefore etc. The major premise is from
Augustine, Enchiridion, chapter 34 Augustinus, Enchiridion, 34 (PL ??)
The minor is clear
in book 3 of the Sentences, distinction 11 Lombard, Sententia, III, d. 2 (II, 27-31) . . Again, the argument made before the opposition is against this conclusion.

In the third place against its corollaries, some act of understanding of the Father precedes the act of generating, therefore the Son was not etenrally. The consequence is clear because the Father was knowing not only in the Son, but also in himself as is clear through
Augustine III De Trinitate Augustinus, De Trinitate, III, ?? (PL ??) . Therefore it seems that the Father had the knowledge of understanding before the expression of the word.

Against the second conclusion is
the second argument made in the opposing arguments Vide supra .

In the second place, if God generates God, therefore he either generates with wisdom or without wisdom. If the first, then the same thing is the terminus from which it was produced and the terminus to which it was produced, which does not seem to be true. If without wisdom, then the Father produces the Son in ingorance, which is false.

Against the third conclusion is
the third argument in the opposition Vide supra .

In the second place, every ratio different from the being in God is posterior to the being itself. However to generate the Son is a denomination or ratio different from the being of God, therefore it is posterior. Therefore it is both prior and posterior. The major premise is proved because in the divine essence there is an order of essential reasons according to
Dionysius, De divinis nominibus, chapter 3 Pseudo-Dionysius, De divinis nominibus, c. 3 (PG ??) . Again, it seems that God is living prior to understanding, and understanding prior to willing. But these by nature precede the generation of the Son, therefore.

In the third place, that which has the ratio of the beginning in some way precedes what it begins. But the Father with respect to the Son and the understanding of the Father with respect to the his speaking has the ratio of the beginning, therefore in some way he precedes This is confirmed because to understand is common to the three suposites but to speak, therefore understanding is prior to speaking.

To the first: the consequence is denied. With respect to the proof I say that not every generation is motion, just as is clear from this. In the second place, it is said according to
James of Viterbo, in the second question of de Divinis Praedicamentis Iacobus de Viterbo
that sometimes a genus indicates an imperfection and a species indicates a perfection, and in such a case the genus is not said about God but the species is appropriately said about God, just as it is clear in the proposed about generation and motion. Sometimes it the converse, and in such a case the genus is said about God but the species is not, just as the universal whole is said about God and the integral whole is not because God does not have parts. Sometimes bot the genus and species speak a perfection and then each is suitable to God. For this it is clear that, granted there is motion superior to generation and the genus, it nevertheless does not follow that since generation is said of God, therefore this is also true of motion.

To the second it is said that Augustine wishes to says that the Virgin did not beget anything except Christ, who according to his humanity is called a creature, as genuit nisi Christum, qui secundum humanitatem potest dici creatura, ut dicit
Lombard says in distinction 11 of the book III Lombardus, Sent. III, d. 11, c. 2, [n.4], (II, 79, ll. 25-26). . This is addressed in a different way in the following.

To the third: the antecedent is denied. With respect to the proof it is said that the knowledge of the Father in himself is not prior to the knowledge of the Son, indeed they are essentially the same.

To the first argument in the opposition: the antecedent is denied, and with respect to the proof the consequence is denied because, though God does not generate another God, nevertheless he generates God the Son, who is different in personhood, but is nevertheless not another God.

To the first argument against the second conclusion, which is the second argument in the opposition,
Hugolinus
would say:
I concede the consequence, while assigning the ratio of it to this. that the Father produces the entire breadth of his cognition into being by saying one word. Therefore therefore there are not many words nor many sons
Hugolinus de Urbi Veteri, ?? . But this does not seem to be a sufficient reason because could still be objected, why through this total immense breadth of cognition did he produce this Son and not a different one. In the second place Brinkel would say to this that
he produced this Son and not another because in God there is only this productive memory and there it is not possible for there to be another. Johannes Brinkel, ?? . But this is similarly not sufficient because it would thus be possible to say anything about any man becuase in him there is only one productive memory and nevertheless he has many words. Again he solves the same through the same and thus does not return an argument, since memory, intelligence, and cognition are in the Son just as in the Father. Therefore I say otherwise that no argument is known to us for why the Father generated this Son and not another, an argument in which the antecedent is known to us from the consequent can be inferred because, given any such reason, it is equally able to be inferred about the Son and the Holy Spirit.

To the second it is said that he generated with wisdom to good sense, ad for the disproof the consequence is denied. Again, it is said that, if the same thing is taken essentially, the consequent is conceded. If personally, then the consequence is denied.

To the third it is said that God generated God, and here this stands for a person. Therefore, in the argument that just as it is conceded that there are three persons, so there are three Gods, the consequence is denied because the Church does not admit that these things are equal.

To the first argument against the third conclusion: the antecedent is denied, and with respect to the proof the consequence is denied. From this it follows that this is not well or sufficiently explained. The third begins through these propositions, a is in the present instant and never was before this, therefore a begins to be, But it ought to be said: a is in this instant of time, etc. And thus it is able to be said about he ceases in its own unique way. To the confirmation, the consequence is denied because he argues from the inferior to the superior with the negation placed before the part of the predicate.

To the second: the major premise is denied. With respect to the confirmation it is said that in the divine essence there is an order of essential reasons, it is said that such order intrinsically should not be admitted in any way, and does not put such an order in the Trinity.

To the third: the antecedent is univerally conceded, but denied in the divine. With respect to the confirmation: whatever is the case regarding the consequent, the consequence is denied because living does not precede understanding, nor does understanding precede willing, and nor does willing precede speaking because, as it was said, there is no priority or posteriority.

Hic oritur quaestio Lombardus, I, d. 4 . This distinction I say contains four conclusions. First: it should be conceded that God generated God and one generated one, nevertheless it should not be conceeded that God generated God himself or another God.
Second conclusion: it is able to be conceded that God the Father generated God which is not the Father.

Third conclusion: faith holds that the three persons are one God, one substance, one essence, and conversely that one essence is three persons. And
the Master Lombard, Sent. I, d. 4, c. 2, [nn. 1-3], (I, 79-80).
proves this through
Augustine I De Trinitate
Augustinus, De Trinitate, I, c. 6, n. 10
to which according to the Master in this matter above all else faith should be consulted. Nevertheless it should be known that some authorities of scripture seem to be against the third conclusion, where uncreated wisdom says about itself,
I am from eternity and before the created age Ecclesiasticus 24:13 . Item,
Father clarify me the Son with the clarity which I had before the world came to be John 17:5 , and all the other similar passages that are able to found. From these passages it is clear that the terms said are signifying about the divine. To the first of these it is said that this authority is understood thus: before the age, that is, if there had been time before the age was in these things or while these things were because, though God co-exists with each part of time, nevertheless properly God is not in time, but in eternity or in an instant of eternity. Thus in the same way the author authorities are able to be solved. From what has been said it is clear that it does not follow: God is not prior because it was not, therefore he begins or began to be.
